message: Happy New Year! I hope you have a happy, healthy, and prosperous 2017. I look forward to my continued work in Congress this year – serving the constituents in #CA09.
Yesterday, my colleagues and I got sworn in to the 115th Congress and took our first votes of the year.

California’s uninsured rate has fallen by 54% since the Affordable Care Act (ACA) was enacted in 2010. This means that 3,826,000 Californians have gained health care coverage. How has the ACA helped you or your family? Share your story in the comments below.

Next week, I will host two open houses for #CA09 constituents. Please join me on Wednesday, January 18th from 4:00-5:30 pm PST at my Stockton office or on Thursday January 19th from 4:00-5:30 pm at my Antioch office. Come by for light refreshments and ask me about issues that are important to you. I hope to see you there!

I am disappointed that the Secretary of the Interior issued an order supporting the WaterFix tunnels. The proposed tunnels threaten to decimate the Delta’s ecosystem, destroy thousands of jobs, and risk the livelihoods of countless Californians. The tunnels are a narrow-minded approach that will do great harm to the Delta region, and should not become a top-priority for the next administration.  http://mcnerney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/thompson-mcnerney-matsui-statement-on-california-waterfix-secretarial

I am happy that Northern California recently received 20 inches of rain and 12 feet of snow. We need to invest in solutions that best recycle, reuse, and capture incoming stormwater. By adopting these solutions, California could save up to 14 million acre-feet of water every year.   http://usat.ly/2iomxqP

Tomorrow (Sunday 1/15), I will be speaking at a rally in Stockton to #SaveHealthcare hosted by Our Revolution San Joaquin County. The event starts at 2 pm PST and is open to the public. Details below.
Today, we honor and celebrate the great legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. His dream continues to live on and inspire us. #MLKDay‬

I will not be attending the inauguration of President-Elect Donald Trump on January 20th. Instead, I will be in my district serving my constituents, as I was elected to do.   The election of Mr. Trump lacks legitimacy due to Russian hacking, which Mr. Trump encouraged, the FBI’s biased involvement, and other irregularities, and I cannot sanction the inauguration by attending the ceremony. However, because I support the peaceful transition of power and respect the office of the presidency, I will work with the new administration when possible to deliver for my district and move our country forward.  http://mcnerney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-mcnerney-releases-statement-on-upcoming-presidential-inauguration
Thanks to everyone who stopped by the open house I hosted today in Stockton. It was great to see so many #CA09 constituents.

The Affordable Care Act has done much more than bring quality, affordable health coverage to millions of Americans. It has increased access to health care in this country by eliminating pre-existing condition exclusions, setting caps on out-of-pocket costs and ensuring families no longer face the threat of bankruptcy due to illness or medical emergencies. The ACA also lowers prescription drug costs for seniors and prevents insurance companies from charging women more for health coverage.  I oppose efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act.  The law is not perfect, but repealing the ACA will shock our health care system, causing millions of people to lose their coverage and costing thousands of lost jobs in my district alone.  Instead of wasting time and resources to repeal a law that benefits millions of people, we should work together to make improvements and build on the progress we’ve made.  https://mcnerney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-mcnerney-issues-statement-opposing-efforts-to-repeal-the-affordable
Thanks to all of the #CA09 constituents who came out to yesterday's open house in my Antioch office. It was great to see everyone.

Last week, I joined so many others in honoring Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s legacy by reading to students at Sierra Vista Homes and Village Community Resource Center. Service and volunteerism, through acts big or small, have the potential to cause lasting change in our community. Whether it is through assisting seniors, cleaning a park, volunteering at a food bank, or reading to children, we can all be of service to our community and make a real difference. #MLKDay

My staff holds mobile office hours each month in Brentwood, Galt, and Stockton. Stop by and get help with federal issues. Details below.   Brentwood: WHEN: First Wednesday of each month  TIME: 10:00am-12:00pm PST WHERE: Brentwood City Hall, 150 City Park Way, 2nd Floor, Brentwood, CA   Galt: WHEN: Second Wednesday of each month  TIME: 10:00am-12:00pm PST WHERE: Galt Flea Market, 610 Chabolla Avenue, Space K28 (on the east side of the Flea Market), Galt, CA  South Stockton:  WHEN: Second Thursday of each month  TIME: 12:00pm-2:00pm PST WHERE: Dorothy L. Jones Family Resource Center, 2044 Fair Street, Stockton, CA

Good luck to David Sanchez III as he competes in the World Players of Handball outdoor cup event this weekend in Stockton! #CA09  http://www.recordnet.com/sports/20170126/young-player-already-accomplished-veteran

President Trump’s executive order on immigration is a sharp departure from our long and proud history of welcoming immigrants to our nation. It unfairly targets individuals based on their religion and country of origin, hurting both refugees who are fleeing persecution and others who have been valuable aides to our military in the fight against terrorism. This policy has already started tearing apart families and will hurt our national security by giving terrorist groups a significant recruiting tool. We need to stand together to repudiate and overturn this destructive policy.  http://mcnerney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-mcnerney-statement-on-president-trump-s-executive-order-on

‪My staff will host mobile office hours tomorrow (Wednesday 2/1) from 10am-12pm PST at Brentwood City Hall (2nd floor), located at 150 City Park Way, Brentwood, CA. Stop by with your questions and get help with federal issues. #CA09

During the month of February, we celebrate Black History Month and the more than 45 million African Americans in our country. African Americans have advanced our society in every field –including the sciences, applied sciences, social sciences, humanities, mathematics, and the arts. African American veterans have valiantly served in every American-fought war since the American Revolution, to protect our freedoms and enhance our democracy. The African American experience is rich in history and all Americans should take the time during this month and throughout the year to reflect, learn, and be inspired by the stories and achievements of African Americans.   If you have the opportunity to visit the nation’s capital, check out the newly-opened Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture.

If we care about our short and long-term future, we must support scientific research and acknowledge the important role that science plays in our society. Watch my speech here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Drj4lFzftB8&t=4s&spfreload=5
Congratulations to University of the Pacific's speech and debate team on taking two No. 1 national rankings!  https://collegeofthepacific.wordpress.com/2017/02/10/pacific-speech-and-debate-is-no-1/

My thoughts and prayers are with everyone affected by the break of the spillway at the Oroville Dam, which has led to nearly 200,000 residents being displaced and put in harm’s way.  It’s important that everyone in an around the Delta region reach safety. For evacuation information and emergency alerts, visit http://www.buttecounty.net/ or call the public information lines listed below:  Oroville Spillway and Butte County Public Information Line: (530) 872-5951  Sutter County Information Lines: (530) 822-4988 or (530) 822-7556

Last week, I had the honor of attending a breakfast with members of the American Federation of Government Employees (AFGE) District 12 to show my support for the hardworking men and women who comprise the federal government workforce. District 12 represents federal workers in California, Nevada, Arizona, and Hawaii who protect our country, administer vital programs, and provide care for our veterans, to name just a few. Our country benefits from a smart and committed federal workforce and we should show our support for these dedicated public servants.

This Saturday (2/18) 10:30am-12pm PST, I will be hosting a town hall with Congressman Mark DeSaulnier and Congressman Mike Thompson on health care and protecting the #ACA. The event will take place at the Contra Costa County Board of Supervisors Chambers, located at 651 Pine Street, Room 107, Martinez, CA 94553. I hope that you can join me!

Reminder: Tomorrow (Saturday 2/18) from 10:30am-12pm PST, I will be hosting a joint town hall on health care with Congressman DeSaulnier and Congressman Thompson. The event will take place at the Contra Costa County Board of Supervisors Chambers, located at 651 Pine Street, Room 107, Martinez, CA 94553.   For those unable to attend, I will be holding another town hall in #CA09 soon. Stay tuned for details!

Thanks to all who attended today's joint health care town hall! We had a great turnout.   I will continue to fight to protect the ACA and to ensure that all Americans have access to quality, affordable health care.

I am very concerned that Scott Pruitt was confirmed to head the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. This poses serious danger for climate change, our environment, and the economy. Read my statement here: http://mcnerney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-mcnerney-statement-on-the-confirmation-of-scott-pruitt-as-epa
Evacuation information and resources for the San Joaquin River levee breach can be found here: https://www.sjgov.org/department/oes/current.

Yesterday, I was honored to join the U.S. Postal Service and members of the Coale family to dedicate the U.S. Post Office at 1408 W. Robinhood Drive in Stockton as the W. Ronald Coale Memorial Post Office.   As many may know, Ron Coale was a pillar of the community and a dedicated public servant to the people of Stockton. He helped propel Stockton forward, most notably in his fight to transform the Port of Stockton into one of the largest and busiest ports in California.   I was proud to author H.R. 1132, to name this post office in his honor. The bill was signed into law by President Barack Obama last year and became Public Law 114-168.

Earlier this week, I went to see first-hand what our growers are experiencing as rains exceed the capacity of our current flood control system. We need to help these communities recover from the immediate harm they’re suffering, and we must be innovative in creating systems that will capture these excessive flows and store them for future use.

As we celebrate National Engineers Week, I want to thank our nation's engineers for their amazing work and their many contributions to our lives today. Engineers have helped meet the major global challenges of our time, including providing state-of-the-art transportation, information technology, enhancing national security, and developing the clean energy technologies needed to power our country into the future. #NationalEngineersWeek

It was wonderful to celebrate the ribbon-cutting ceremony for the opening of the Discovery Challenge Academy, a California National Guard Youth ChalleNGe Program to help at-risk teens in San Joaquin County. This program has helped many at-risk young people learn valuable life skills, establish a strong work ethic, and develop a commitment to community service. I’m happy to have been able to help bring this vital, successful program to San Joaquin County. I look forward to seeing the positive impact that it will have on the young people in our community.

I’m proud to earn a 100% score on League of Conservation Voters ' 2016 National Environmental Scorecard. LCV scores votes on the most important issues of the year, including energy, global warming, public health, public lands and wildlife conservation, and spending for environmental programs. http://scorecard.lcv.org/moc/jerry-mcnerney

I will be hosting a town hall in Stockton this coming Sunday, March 5th, from 6-7:30 pm PST to discuss issues of importance to you and our community. The event will take place at Mayfair Seventh Day Adventist Church, located at 6940 N. El Dorado Street, Stockton, CA 95207). I hope to see you there! #CA09

Next Tuesday (March 7th) from 6-7:30 pm PST, my staff and representatives from Contra Costa County Public Works and the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) will host a flood map and insurance resource workshop. New flood maps will take effect on March 21st. Stop by to learn about the effect they will have on your property and insurance rates. The workshop will take place at Excelsior Middle School, located at 14301 Byron Highway, Byron, CA, 94514.
It was great stopping by KQED earlier today. Tune in to KQED Newsroom tonight at 7pm PST on KQED Public TV Channel 9.

Proud to announce that yesterday I introduced the Securing IoT Act. The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices creates immense opportunities for our society, including new jobs and efficiencies in all aspects of our everyday lives. However, the security of these devices has not kept up with the rapid pace of innovation and deployment. Security vulnerabilities in IoT devices are likely to pose threats to our national security and endanger our nation’s economy. My legislation helps to address these concerns by requiring that security standards be established for IoT devices and that these devices be certified to meet those standards.
Check out my interview with KQED Newsroom: https://ww2.kqed.org/news/2017/03/03/uc-sexual-misconduct-congressman-jerry-mcnerney-assemblyman-chad-mayes-the-trocks/

I hope you can join me tomorrow (March 5th) from 6-7:30pm PST for my town hall in Stockton, taking place at Mayfair Seventh Day Adventist Church (6940 N. El Dorado Street). I look forward to discussing issues that are important to you and our community. #CA09
Stockton Town Hall

A major shout out to Pastor Sylvester and the Mayfair SDA church for hosting last night’s town hall meeting in Stockton. Pastor Sylvester did an excellent job in running the meeting. He is a true gentleman. I also want to thank all the participants for their involvement, heartfelt questions, and courtesy during the meeting. Thank you to Vice Mayor Holman and Councilwoman Loftus for their participation. I will be holding another town hall in Antioch on Saturday, March 11th from 10:30am-12pm at Deer Valley High School (4700 Lone Tree Way) which will also be livestreamed via Facebook Live.

Tomorrow (March 7th) from 6-7:30 pm PST, my staff and representatives from Contra Costa County Public Works and the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) will host a flood map and insurance resource workshop. The workshop will take place at Excelsior Middle School, located at 14301 Byron Highway, Byron, CA, 94514.

ICYMI: My interview with @KQED Newsroom where I call for Attorney General Jeff Sessions to resign, and discuss the lack of transparency in the GOP's efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act, the need to improve security in Internet of Things devices, and the dangers posed by cutting the Environmental Protection Agency's budget: https://ww2.kqed.org/news/2017/03/03/uc-sexual-misconduct-congressman-jerry-mcnerney-assemblyman-chad-mayes-the-trocks/.

The Republican’s #ACA repeal bill that is being marked up by the House Energy and Commerce Committee today will cause millions of people to lose their health care coverage. Since the ACA was enacted, California’s uninsured rate has fallen by 54% and more than 3.8 million Californians have gained health coverage, including over 263,000 people in Contra Costa, Sacramento, and San Joaquin Counties.   Watch my opening statement from today’s markup here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L365xmnRvv0

We are now heading into the 12th hour of the #ACA repeal bill markup in the House Energy and Commerce Committee. This flawed legislation would strip millions of Americans of their health care coverage. I am here fighting to #ProtectOurCare. Watch live: https://democrats-energycommerce.house.gov/committee-activity/markups/markup-of-republican-aca-repeal-bill-full-committee-march-8-2017

Sharing a video on the heels of a 27-hour House Energy and Commerce Committee markup of the Republican’s bill to repeal and replace the #ACA. The Republicans jammed the bill through the committee without taking the time to examine how this flawed legislation will impact health costs and coverage for millions of Americans. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ROjG6xLAhV4

I hope you can join me tomorrow (Saturday, March 11th) from 10:30am-12pm PST for my town hall in Antioch, taking place at Deer Valley High School, West Cafeteria (4700 Lone Tree Way, Antioch, CA 94531). I look forward to discussing issues that are important to you and our community. #CA09
Antioch Town Hall
Happy Pi Day! As the only mathematician in Congress, I wanted to share a few things with you about Pi: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F14JvKx4tMY&feature=youtu.be.

Congratulations to Nathaniel Chien of #CA09 on receiving the Congressional Award Silver Medal. Nathaniel is a student at Lincoln High School and has contributed over 100 hours of voluntary public service to the community. Thanks for your service, Nathaniel!

Check out my recent interview with Pacific Standard, where i offer my perspective on being a scientist in Congress and the challenges we currently face: https://psmag.com/what-its-like-to-be-a-scientist-in-congress-jerry-mcnerney-be28a172bac6#.7q6q4nyxm.
Thanks to everyone who came to my town hall in Antioch last weekend. It was great to hear from and see so many #CA09 constituents.
This afternoon, the Republicans did what I have asked for all week – to withdraw their terrible bill. Now, maybe they will work with us in a bipartisan way to improve the Affordable Care Act.

I will continue to fight to protect the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and the coverage it provides for millions of people. Although I am strongly opposed to a repeal of the ACA, I believe we should be looking for ways to improve and build off of its success. In doing so we should consider the following:  • Offer a public option in areas where there are limited insurance options • Improve premium assistance so that it works for more individuals and families • End the Cadillac Tax • Increase price transparency for patients  • Allow the government to negotiate drug prices in the Medicare program   The fight to protect and improve our health care system is not over. I am proud of what we have accomplished so far, and I am looking forward to working in a bipartisan way to improve health care for all. I urge my Republican colleagues to stop trying to sabotage the ACA and start working to improve it.
Remembering historical icon César Chávez today and his tireless advocacy for workers' rights, social justice, and civil liberties.

On Saturday, April 8th from 10:30am-12:00pm PDT, I will be hosting a joint town hall in Antioch with Rep. Mark DeSaulnier. I hope you can join us.   https://www.facebook.com/events/732852300219186/?ti=icl

I am very disappointed that President Trump signed legislation into law that strips consumers of their online privacy and security. Despite a loud cry from the American people that they want to be able to choose how their information is used, this law leaves consumers without the power to choose how their internet service provider (ISP) uses and shares their information. It also leaves consumers more vulnerable to cyber attacks because ISPs will no longer be required to take reasonable steps to secure consumers’ personal information. Given the growing cyber threats that our nation faces, it is critical that we do more, not less, to secure consumers’ data. I will continue to fight for strong online privacy and security protections for consumers.  Check out my remarks from last week’s floor debate on this legislation: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IV91Trhed_c&feature=youtu.be.

The American people are increasingly concerned about allegations that President Trump and members of his Administration colluded with Russia to influence the presidential election. In January, U.S. Intelligence agencies concluded with high confidence that Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered an influence campaign in 2016 aimed at undermining the U.S. presidential election, and there is growing evidence that Trump’s campaign aides had frequent contact with Russian officials before, during, and after the election.   Many of my colleagues and I have called for a special prosecutor or an independent, bipartisan commission to investigate any ties between President Trump and Russia. An investigation is essential to upholding the integrity of our democracy and our national security. The President and Administration officials should welcome transparency and oversight, and should give their full cooperation to help assure the American people that there is no truth to these allegations.

President Trump’s FY18 budget blueprint would completely eliminate the Minority Business Development Agency (MBDA), which is the sole federal agency with the mission to promote the growth of minority-owned businesses. In response, I led two bipartisan letters to the House Appropriations Committee imploring Congress to fund the MBDA in the FY2018 appropriations, and recommending that MBDA provide an annual policy report to Congress to address gaps in equity between minority and non-minority owned firms.  We must make every effort to empower and support the growth of minority-owned businesses; their contributions to local economies and communities cannot be overstated.Funding the MBDA is and will remain a priority.  https://mcnerney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-mcnerney-leads-bipartisan-effort-to-save-the-minority-business

The chemical attacks carried out by the Assad regime are an attack on humanity and yet another horrible outcome from the turmoil gripping Syria and the surrounding region. We need a comprehensive solution to end this violence and a clear strategy that includes regional and international partnerships. Congress must be consulted on any future plans for military action.
Joint Town Hall with Congressman Mark DeSaulnier

As a scientist, public servant and American, I will continue to fight against the War on Science. Without investment in science and scientific discovery, America would not be the thriving hub for innovation that it is today. From medical advancements to new technologies, the American commitment to science has contributed to our economic success and national security. Check out my op-ed in The Hill for more about the history of the War on Science and the need to protect the integrity of truth and fact in our democracy. http://bit.ly/2oPaCWI
Today’s students are tomorrow’s leaders. A special thanks to the Civil Engineering Department at the University of the Pacific for the opportunity to speak with the next generation of innovators.

There are many ways to celebrate Earth Day today and all year long - from planting a tree in your community to taking steps to reduce your carbon footprint. No matter how you celebrate, let's join together and do our part to protect the environment and our planet.

It was an honor to receive this year’s Pioneer in Healthcare Policy Award from the Society for Brain Mapping and Therapeutics and the Brain Mapping Foundation. The critical work done by these organizations is helping to advance research to improve treatment and move us one step further toward finding cures for the difficult diseases and disorders of the central nervous system. I am proud to be this year’s Healthcare Policy Award recipient, and to have been accompanied by my daughter, Windy – a neuroscientist who works on the biochemistry of neurodegenerative disorders at the VA.

Don't miss out on a great opportunity to showcase the talented young artists in our district! This Friday is the deadline for the 2017 National Congressional Art Competition. For more on the guidelines: http://bit.ly/2p1uDJ7
Great questions from a group of Lodi High School seniors last week. We tackled everything from local issues to what's going on in Washington. Stay inquisitive!
NAACP Town Hall in Stockton

I know firsthand that renewable energy creates jobs and economic opportunity. As Republicans weigh their options for tax reform, they have an opportunity to incentivize growth and combat climate change.  https://youtu.be/7PTqERY7f6Q

Small businesses are the backbone of the American economy, and create two out of every three new jobs each year. That’s why I introduced the Small Business Relief and Job Creation Act. By incentivizing companies to hire those most in need, we can put Americans back to work and strengthen our economy. http://bit.ly/2oZlUsz

Millions of Americans, and more than 263,000 constituents of mine, have health insurance because of the Affordable Care Act. Let's not jeopardize that coverage, and instead work together to improve what we have and give Americans the healthcare they need.
I'm deeply disappointed with the outcome of today's vote. Americans deserve better. http://bit.ly/2q4dbFR
This week I was proud to introduce the Small Business Relief and Job Creation Act. Let's help Americans get back to work and give small businesses the tools they need to succeed.
We may have hit a setback, but we're not going to let that stop us. We're going to continue to push forward on behalf of the American people.

While former FBI Director Comey’s conduct has been gravely concerning, the timing of his dismissal is troubling.  This move by President Trump only serves to increase the American people’s anxiety regarding allegations that he and members of his Administration colluded with Russia to influence the democratic outcome of our elections. They have an opportunity to restore the people’s faith in our government by supporting transparency and oversight, and have failed to do so with this egregious abuse of power.    As I’ve stated before, we need a special prosecutor or an independent, bipartisan commission to investigate any allegations of misconduct or attempts to undermine our democracy and national security. I stand with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to ensure that we reach a fair, independent, and exhaustive conclusion to this issue. The American people deserve answers to these very serious and dangerous accusations.

I hope you'll join me as I announce a new legislative initiative that would be an alternative to the tunnels. Californians deserve a comprehensive and forward-thinking solution that will ensure long-term water stability, and WaterFix is not the answer.   We need a plan for water reform that will benefit all Californians and serve as a model to modernize our national water infrastructure.  For more information, please feel free to call my office in Stockton: (209)-476-8552.

California’s 9th Congressional District is made up of a thriving and inclusive community that I am proud to represent, and as a member of the Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus, I hope you’ll join me in celebrating Asian Pacific American Heritage Month throughout the month of May. Our communities are stronger because of the contributions and impact made by our diverse citizenry.
As we celebrate #NationalPoliceWeek, I'm proud to congratulate the Stockton Police Department on winning the National Officer Wellness Award.

A lot happened in Washington this week, and while Mr. Mueller's appointment was a good first step, I'm going to keep pushing for an independent, bipartisan commission to ensure full transparency. But I'm also going to continue to work on your behalf to address the critical issues that affect us everyday.
As the proud parent of a veteran, I hope you'll join me in thanking the brave men and women who serve in our military this #ArmedForcesDay.

When an officer gives their life in the line of duty, it is a tragedy for their families and for the entire community. Today I called on the Postmaster General and urged her to establish a stamp to honor our fallen officers and donate the proceeds of that stamp to the officers' families. http://bit.ly/2q8NnIR

Today I had the privilege of hosting two outstanding young Californians, Shantell House and Jeremiah McWright, who joined me for the annual Congressional Youth Foster Shadow Day. As a member of the Youth Foster Caucus, I was honored to participate in this program and had the opportunity to highlight their stories on the House floor.
ICYMI: Here's what happened in my office in Washington last week. I had some really positive meetings, but there were also some challenges that I'm going to continue to tackle on your behalf.
I hope he recognizes this opportunity and seizes it.

I’m greatly disappointed, though unfortunately not surprised that President Trump has decided to pull the United States out of the Paris Climate Accord. This decision is wrongheaded and a dangerous mistake that will have a devastating impact on future generations.   The Paris Accord brings together the collective resources of governments around the world in order to reduce emissions, and has motivated the biggest emitters – such as China and India – to take strong steps toward reducing emissions in their countries.   Climate change is one of the biggest issues facing our nation and our planet. We’ve seen a rise in extreme weather events, rising sea levels, and other health-related consequences of harmful emissions. This affects our lives in every way, including public health, economic growth, and our environment. The United States needs to remain a leader in combating and mitigating the effects of climate change. The President’s decision is a step backward.  President Trump and his advisors are pushing policies that are threatening the safety and well-being of every American, and of future generations around the world. This decision is willfully ignorant, dangerous, and without reason or justification, and I will continue to fight back against any measures that threaten the future of our country and our planet.
This week, I was back in the district where we have a lot of exciting new initiatives underway, including an expansion of the Contra Costa health care facility in Brentwood.

We must invest in forward-thinking solutions to address the water supply needs of Californians and the long-term policy goals of our nation's water security. That's why I introduced the Western Water Recycling and Drought Relief Act, which calls on Congress to authorize 23 regional water recycling projects.  http://bit.ly/2rCADsY

Today is the 111th anniversary of the Antiquities Act, which was signed into law by President Theodore Roosevelt and has been used by presidents throughout history to protect national monuments across the country - including the 15 found in California. From the Cascade-Siskiyou National Monument in the north to the Cabrillo National Monument in the south, these national treasures offer the people of California and visitors from around the world a chance to explore our history and wilderness.

This week, House Republicans passed legislation to roll back major consumer protections that were put in place after the financial and housing crisis of 2007 - which hit our district particularly hard. But we're not going backward and I'm going to keep working on your behalf to ensure Americans can attain the financial security they need to succeed.

This morning, a random act of violence took place while the Republican Congressional baseball team was practicing for the annual Congressional baseball game – a bipartisan charity event where both parties come together for a common good.  Any individual who enacts such violence is not only hurting those caught in these senseless instances, but also their families, themselves and the greater community.   My thoughts and thanks are with the Capitol Police and local law enforcement who quickly contained the situation and who work every day to keep our country safe.  I also want to extend my deepest sympathies to those officers and staff who were victims of this tragic event, and to Congressman Steve Scalise and his family. Steve is a friend and a gentleman, and I wish him a speedy recovery so that we can all continue to benefit from his participation in our democracy.
I'll be joining my colleagues this evening at the Congressional baseball game, but before I go, I wanted to talk with you about what happened in Washington this week.
Great game! Congratulations to everyone who worked hard and played well tonight.

Last week, the Golden State Warriors brought home a great victory. I wanted to make sure they got a mention in the official record, and my good friend Congressman Mike Doyle wanted to do the same for his hometown team.

The Starry Nights in Brentwood concert series is a great way to end the week by spending time with friends and neighbors, enjoying great music in beautiful City Park. Mary and I had a great time catching up with everyone, including Mayor Taylor and his son Paul.

A lot of great things are happening in Stockton, and I'm proud to represent this all-American city. Congratulations! http://www.recordnet.com/news/20170616/stockton-named-all-america-city-for-fourth-time

So much of the negative and nasty rhetoric that fuels partisan rancor is financed through outside spending. I'm proud to be one of the co-founders of the Congressional Campaign Finance Reform Caucus and look forward to working with my colleagues from both sides on ways to reduce the role of excessive spending in our elections.

I joined with my Northern California colleagues to continue to oppose the tunnels. The recent opinions ignore scientific fact and will cause irreparable harm to the Delta and to my constituents.  https://mcnerney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/northern-california-congreassional-delegation-blasts-waterfix-biological

Today, I had the honor of hosting Bishop Stephen Blaire, who oversees the Diocese of Stockton. After he led members in the opening prayer, I spoke on the floor and shared some words of wisdom from Bishop Blaire that I think my colleagues and I could all learn from.

Over 2 million adults and 649,000 children in California have asthma. In our district, we've led the way to being one of the most effective areas to utilize funding to reduce carbon emissions. This is particularly important for those suffering from asthma and respiratory issues. We can't allow anyone to push back this progress, which helps so many people.

Happy #FourthOfJuly! Today we celebrate the birth of our democracy. It's a time to honor the men and women who serve and protect us, and to celebrate the freedoms they preserve. Wishing you and your family a safe and happy #IndependenceDay!

It's always a pleasure to see my good friend C.C. Yin, founder and Chair of the Asian Pacific Islander American Public Affairs (APAPA). This active organization is utilizing civic engagement to do great things in their community!

Congratulations to Linden, CA native Aaron Judge on his incredible victory at the 2017 Home Run Derby! Aaron is another example of the talent and drive in our district. https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/mlb/allstar/2017/07/11/home-run-derby-aaron-judge/466908001/

Today is a national day of action to raise awareness about the need to protect #netneutrality and an open internet. Without net neutrality, internet providers could create fast and slow lanes, speeding up or slowing down internet traffic. For those who could not afford the fast lane, like small businesses and start-ups, they could be discriminated against and disadvantaged compared to their larger competitors. Entrepreneurs and innovators benefit from strong net neutrality protections and so do consumers. We must protect net neutrality.
Getting ready to chat live with Congressman Mike Doyle about #netneutrality.

Right now, we're debating H.R. 23 - a California water bill that would weaken environmental laws and harm Northern Californians to benefit a few wealthy people in the south. I spoke out against this legislation and urge my colleagues: let's work together on a solution that will benefit all Californians.

I voted against H.R. 23 and its divisive California water proposal. Read my full statement on its passage in the House. https://mcnerney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-mcnerney-statement-on-divisive-california-water-bill

Too many Americans are still trying to get back on their feet, and our focus should be on finding ways to help them. That's way I'm proud to introduce legislation that's supported by IBEW local 595 and Richard Trumka and the AFL-CIO, which would crack down on companies who abuse corporate tax loopholes and continue to ship jobs out of the country. We must hold these companies accountable.

There was a lot that happened in Washington this week, including the unfortunate passage of a disastrous California water bill in the House of Representatives. But on Monday I'll be announcing my alternative plan to this bill and to the WaterFix tunnels proposal. I hope to see you there!
Press Conference: Congressman McNerney's Plan for A Sustainable Water Future
Press Conference: Congressman McNerney's Plan for A Sustainable Water Future
Press Conference: Congressman McNerney's Plan for A Sustainable Water Future
Press Conference: Congressman McNerney's Plan for A Sustainable Water Future

It’s time to shift the narrative. For too long, California’s water sustainability has focused on shipping water from one region to another. These solutions create short-term, expensive fixes that don’t generate new water. My new legislation, the WEST Act, changes the discussion by bringing water conservation to the forefront, focusing on sustainability through innovative and technologically advanced solutions. https://mcnerney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-mcnerney-unveils-comprehensive-water-legislation
Thanks to everyone who came out to support my new proposal yesterday. Let's build a sustainable water future for all Californians!

Sadly, the world has lost a great young mind and a pioneer for women in the field of mathematics. Born in Iran, Maryam Mirzakhani broke barriers for women in her country and was the first woman to win the Fields Medal - the mathematical equivalent of the Nobel Prize. She will be dearly missed by her colleagues at Stanford University, her family and friends, and the mathematics community that she contributed so much to advancing.

The recent string of cyber attacks reinforces the need to have a serious discussion about grid modernization. This week, I was proud to introduce bipartisan legislation that would create public-private partnerships with industry officials and regulators to update our grid system to handle the 21st century challenges we're facing.

As co-chair of the bipartisan Grid Innovation Caucus, one of my key objectives is to push Congress to address the issue of grid modernization. The American energy grid is the backbone of our economy and touches every aspect of our lives. We must bring our aging system into the 21st century. Today, I was pleased to join co-chair Bob Latta at the Grid Innovation Expo, where industry leaders shared some of the forward-thinking ways they are working on grid security and reliability.
Great to have Fathers & Families of San Joaquin stop by my office to talk about how to give youths in our community a hand up. And thanks for bringing me some new decorations!
Joined Planned Parenthood to rally for healthcare. Americans have made it clear that this bill is not what they need. It's time to listen to them.

Self-driving cars are the future, and this week in the House we moved forward with legislation to make sure these vehicles are safe and reduce traffic and parking costs. On the Senate side, though, there was another attempt to take away healthcare from millions of Americans, but three brave Republicans stood their ground.   I'll be home for the month of August and hope to see and speak with you about what issues you're most concerned with.
National Startup Day: Congressman McNerney Tours Huddle Cowork

I had a great time touring Huddle Cowork in Stockton today. This shared workspace is opening up opportunities for entrepreneurs to grow their businesses and collaborate with others looking to expand. Several businesses have even gone on to open up their own stores downtown! Let's continue to promote and enable a #startup culture in our community.

Keeping police-community bonds strong begins with supporting the partnerships between law enforcement and the people they serve. Community events, such as National Night Out, have proven to be an effective tool in combating violence and maintaining safety within our neighborhoods. Thanks to everyone who came out to support these efforts!

It's been a great week back in the district, and I've had the opportunity to visit several facilities that are contributing so much to our community - including the Children's Home of Stockton and La Clinica de La Raza in Oakley.

We are already seeing the detrimental effects of climate change. Now, more than ever, it is imperative that we commit to combating this imminent threat.  https://mobile.nytimes.com/2017/08/07/climate/climate-change-drastic-warming-trump.html?emc=edit_na_20170807&nl=breaking-news&nlid=12722706&ref=cta&_r=0&referer

Employing military action in any capacity is an incredibly serious decision. This administration’s current rhetoric regarding North Korea is reckless and further illustrates the need for continued Congressional oversight and diplomatic options in addressing potential threats from North Korea.

I hope you can join me next Tuesday, August 15th for a town hall focusing on the issues that affect our veterans and their families. I'll be joined by representatives from the Department of Veterans Affairs and the Army Corps of Engineers, and we'll be giving an update on the progress of the French Camp VA clinic.   If you have any questions, or would like to RSVP, please call my Stockton office: (209) 476-8552.

The Stockton Police Department has been nationally recognized for their success in reducing crime. If the Department of Justice is truly committed to public safety, they will seek other opportunities to support our local law enforcement, not threaten to withhold essential funding. https://mcnerney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-mcnerney-pushes-back-on-threat-to-local-law-enforcement-funding
Next Tuesday I'll be hosting a town hall with Assemblymember Susan Talamantes Eggman. I hope you can join us to discuss the issues and concerns that are most important to you.
It was great to see so many of you out at the Stand Down last night, working together to help give back to the veterans who have given us so much.

Today, white supremacists carried out acts of hatred and violence in Charlottesville, Virginia. It is the responsibility of all of our nation's leaders to condemn these actions. Our country must stand strong in the face of hate and intolerance.

Reminder: I'll be hosting two town halls tomorrow.   In the morning, I'll be joined by representatives from the Department of Veterans Affairs to discuss the progress of the French Camp VA clinic and issues that are important to our veterans.  Tomorrow evening, Assemblymember Susan Talamantes Eggman and I will be hosting a joint town hall to discuss the issues and concerns of our community.  If you have questions, or would like to RSVP, please call my Stockton office at (209) 476-8552.   I hope to see many of you tomorrow!
Congressman Jerry McNerney's Veterans Town Hall
We're live at the Veterans Town Hall, where we'll be hearing an update on the French Camp VA clinic progress and discussing issues affecting our nation's veterans.

Great turnout for our Veteran's Town Hall! I'll continue to keep you updated on the progress of the French Camp VA clinic, and I'll never stop being a voice for our veterans. I hope to see more of you this evening in Mountain House at our next town hall.
Congressman Jerry McNerney's Town Hall in Mountain House
Tune in now for my town hall with Assemblymember Susan Talamantes Eggman.

Yesterday’s press conference was yet another example of the President’s complete lack of leadership. His unwillingness to condemn the white supremacists and Neo-Nazis who carried out violent acts of hatred in Charlottesville this weekend is inexcusable. You cannot use the bully pulpit to make excuses for hatemongers and you cannot use the office of the presidency to provoke violence, domestically or with leaders abroad. These past few weeks have further proven this President is incapable of effectively uniting and leading our nation.

I hope you'll join me next Wednesday for an open house at my office in Antioch. I'm looking forward to discussing what issues and concerns are important to you, and giving you all an update on what's happening in Washington.
I hope to see you on Wednesday for an open house at my Antioch office.
I'm talking live with KRON 4 News about issues affecting our district and what I'm working on in Washington.
Great discussions at my Antioch office this week. Thanks to everyone who stopped by!

Today and throughout this week, we are all Texans as our hearts go out to those hurt by this monster storm. Thank you to the first responders who have put their own lives at risk to save others, and to the volunteers working tirelessly to provide shelter and food for those in need.  If you are looking for opportunities to help those affected, please follow FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency for updates.

The Patriots Jet Team is the largest civilian-owned aerobatic jet team in the western hemisphere. These experienced pilots – many who have served in the U.S. and Canadian military – have performed over 1500 air shows.   They also have a volunteer-run foundation to encourage students to become involved in aviation and STEM career paths. They even let me try out one of their piloting simulations used to give students an opportunity to experience “life in the left seat.”   Thanks to the Patriots Jet Team & Byron Airport for the tour and the great work they’re doing to help kids explore STEM possibilities!

Instead of tackling the real problem that is our broken immigration system, this administration wants to roll back a policy that has helped hundreds of thousands of children and families. For many DACA recipients – who often come to the U.S. fleeing dire situations – this is the only home they have ever known and they proudly call themselves Americans.   It's heartbreaking that our children and their families are facing such hateful rhetoric and unprecedented targeting at the hands of this administration. We must commit to reforms that will allow people, who have long contributed to our nation, to feel safe knowing their families will not be torn apart.

Wishing you all a safe and happy Labor Day. Our country would not be where it is today without the hard-working women & men across this nation who drive our economy forward with their strength, knowledge, skills, and determination. Thanks to our diligent workforce for their endless contributions.

This morning I joined my Democratic colleagues from the House and Senate to pledge our support to the DREAMers. Right now, we have bipartisan legislation that would fill the gap left behind by the termination of DACA, which will leave hundreds of thousands of young people at risk for deportation. Some of my Republican colleagues have expressed concern over the decision to end DACA, and I hope they'll join me in calling on Republican leadership to immediately bring the DREAM Act to the floor so our DREAMers - who contribute so much to our communities - can have peace of mind.
I'll be live with my House Democrats colleagues talking about why we must #ProtectDREAMers and what that means to our district.

Congress has a big agenda this month, and last week was a good start as Democratic leadership in the House and Senate came together with the president to reach a bipartisan agreement to keep the government open and provide relief for Hurricane Harvey victims. Unfortunately, though, the president also announced a plan to end the DACA program. But in Congress, we have bipartisan legislation that would fill the hole left behind by this program's termination. Let's pass the DREaM Act immediately.

To say that I am incredibly troubled by the Equifax data breach is an understatement. Hardworking Americans, who already face so many challenges, must now also worry whether their most sensitive information, such as their Social Security and driver’s license numbers, has been stolen by criminals. It is imperative that Congress immediately scrutinize what happened and what risks now exist to the public as a result of this breach. Did Equifax take adequate steps to protect such sensitive information for so many people, and did it respond quickly and appropriately to the attack? What does this episode tell us about current vulnerabilities?   Clearly, the scope and damage of such incidents are growing. I have long fought for strong data security protection for consumers. Given the growing cyber threats that our nation faces, it is critical that Congress enact safeguards for consumer, corporate, and national security information as expeditiously as possible.

We will never forget the thousands of Americans who lost their lives on September 11th, and the first responders who rushed to the scene to save so many more. My thoughts and prayers are with the families of those who are mourning the loss of a loved one today.

Today I joined my Democratic colleagues from the Energy and Commerce Committee to push for answers and insight into Equifax's massive data breach. It is unacceptable that it took Equifax over a month to disclose that the sensitive information of 143 million Americans was compromised. We must know what they are doing to help these consumers and how they plan to protect against future hacks. https://democrats-energycommerce.house.gov/newsroom/press-releases/ec-dems-question-equifax-on-massive-data-breach
Great meeting with PORAC (Peace Officers Research Association of California). I'm glad to have their support for my bill to reduce gang violence and recidivism rates.
My good friend Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer says it all. I'm proud to join my colleagues to call for passage of the DREAM Act.

I'm proud to be in Sacramento this evening, joining some of my California colleagues to talk about the need to pass the DREAM Act and to hear from some of our DREAMers. This is an immediate need, but we must also continue to work toward comprehensive immigration reform.

Across the state, Californians are standing up for what's right. I have never been so proud to be a Californian - and I've been proud for a very long time. We must #protectDREAMers and work toward comprehensive immigration reform.

Today, the Westlands Water District voted against participation in the WaterFix tunnels proposal. This opens up an opportunity to discuss alternative solutions to California's water challenges. See below for my full statement. https://mcnerney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-mcnerney-statement-on-westlands-vote-against-the-tunnels

Recently, I had the pleasure of sitting down for breakfast with some of UC Berkeley's undergraduate STEM students.   They also took me on a tour of some of Berkeley's nuclear engineering labs, excitedly showing me a number of tests and projects they were working on. It's always a pleasure to spend time with the innovators of tomorrow!

My heart goes out to the people of Mexico and the first responders and volunteers who have been working on recovery efforts over the past few days.  Our countries often help each other in times of need, and just as Mexico quickly offered assistance in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey, we have sent a team to help with their recovery. http://abcnews.go.com/International/us-search-rescue-experts-arrive-mexico-deadly-earthquake/story?id=50001881
Today we honor our Gold Star mothers and Gold Star families, and remember the legacy of their loved ones who gave their lives in service to our country.

Today, the Senate announced that they will not hold a vote on the Graham-Cassidy bill, the Republican’s latest attempt to repeal the Affordable Care Act. This proposal would have been devastating for millions of Americans, especially in California, where 6.7 million people were at risk to lose health coverage. Additionally, the bill would cost the state billions in federal assistance.   I call on my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to come together and work on meaningful legislation that will maintain and improve access to quality affordable health care for all Americans.

Since coming to Congress to work for you, veterans and veterans’ care has been one of my top priorities. Today, I had a productive meeting with Tony Fitzgerald, the new Director of the VA’s Palo Alto Health Care System. We discussed the challenges our local facilities are facing, and I look forward to continuing to work with Tony on finding solutions that will ensure our veterans receive the highest quality care. Too many of our local veterans have to travel hours to get a routine medical appointment and that’s why I fought to get the money appropriated for the new French Camp clinic. The money for French Camp has been secured, now the VA must do its part to get the facility constructed.   Additionally, I expressed to Tony my concerns about the Livermore facilities – which many of my constituents utilize – and the need for this institution to remain in the hands of the VA. I remain committed to working with anyone who shares a passion for helping improve the lives of the men and women who serve our nation.
Thank you to Savonnda and Jose - both Stockton residents - for coming to Washington to share how the Affordable Care Act has positively impacted their lives.

Our military leaders have declared the need for more aid in Puerto Rico, and local officials are begging for our help. Millions of American citizens are without food and water, and their homes have been destroyed in what is becoming a full-blown humanitarian crisis. The situation is urgent - we can and must do more to help our fellow Americans recover from this devastation.

I’m extremely disappointed that Richard Smith, the former CEO of Equifax, could not adequately answer many of the questions my colleagues and I asked him today. Millions of Americans were affected by this breach and are now more susceptible to their information being stolen and used for identity theft and other harmful purposes.  https://www.cnet.com/news/equifax-ex-ceo-blames-breach-on-one-person-and-a-bad-scanner/

Today I joined my Democratic Colleagues to demand common sense gun reforms be brought before the House. More can and must be done to protect the American people. As Congresswoman Gabby Giffords said, we must be bold and courageous because the nation is counting on us.
NEA Today works to advance public education in our nation and I was proud to meet with them today to discuss a number of issues facing our educators and our students.

Praying for our neighbors caught in the path of these dangerous wildfires. If you or someone you know is currently in an evacuation zone, please follow the directives from local authorities and leave the area. Evacuation shelters are open, including shelters to safely take in pets. http://www.sacbee.com/news/local/article177893206.html

Broadband access will make a big difference for the more than 20 million veterans throughout our nation. That's why I introduced bipartisan legislation to improve connectivity for our nation's heroes. Closing the digital divide means increased job and educational opportunities and better access to VA resources, and this bill will set us on that path. https://mcnerney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-mcnerney-continues-fights-for-veterans-with-bipartisan-broadband

As we continue to combat these dangerous wildfires, please stay alert for public safety and health warnings. Smoke has settled in the Stockton area, degrading local air quality. It is recommended that you avoid outdoor activity. http://www.recordnet.com/news/20171011/very-unhealthy-air-avoid-outdoor-activity/1

This week, I took to the House floor to urge my colleagues to stand up for clean energy, our environment and to take positive action to address climate change. That's why I support the Clean Power Plan. We can't afford to roll back progress.
Disaster assistance is available for those suffering losses due to the fires in Sonoma and Napa County.

Our country’s economic growth will be determined in large part by the innovation and expansion of technology and STEM-focused businesses. That means it is critical to the growth of our economy that Minority-Serving Institutions, such as CSU Stanislaus, and minority-owned businesses are connected to this technological ecosystem.

My office is hosting an information session for high school students interested in attending a military service academy.   If you or someone you know is interested, please join us this Thursday, October 19th from 7:00-9:00 PM at the Ronald McNair High School Theater in Stockton.  https://mcnerney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-mcnerney-to-host-military-service-academy-information-session

Thanks to the students at Deer Valley High School for inviting me to their class.   They had a lot of questions about what’s going on in our government, and were particularly concerned about how policy debates around immigration reform and healthcare could affect their friends and families.

I recently toured the Vasco Caves Regional Preserve, which is home to a stunning display of fragile natural resources. Our natural resources are some of our greatest treasures, and I am proud to support conservation efforts such as these.

Reminder: Tonight, my office is hosting an information session for high school students interested in attending a military service academy.  Please join us this evening at the Ronald McNair High School Theater in Stockton. Staff will be on hand to answer questions from 7:00 - 9:00 PM.

Each year, my office collects thousands of cards to send to our our brave men and women in uniform through my annual 'Holiday Cards for Our Troops' program. If you would like to participate, please follow the guidelines in the link below and be sure to get your cards to my office in Stockton or Anitoch by November 17th.  https://mcnerney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-mcnerney-announces-2017-holiday-cards-for-the-troops-program

Today, I joined my friend and neighbor, Congressman Mike Thompson, in a moment of silence for victims of the devastating California wildfires. We must remain committed to helping our fellow Californians, and I will continue to work and do all that I can to assist as they rebuild.

Today, it was announced that the Trump administration would not support the California Waterfix Project. But, long before this administration weighed in, the controversial tunnels proposal has been based on flawed science and funding assumptions without even achieving water sustainability for the state. Most recently, support has shifted away from the project due to its excessive cost that comes with no assurance of prolonged results. For these reasons, opposition to the tunnels continues to grow.  There are many viable alternatives and forward-thinking approaches that will modernize our water system. My new legislation, the WEST Act, focuses on these tangible, commonsense solutions, including conservation, efficiency, recycling, and water capture.  It’s time to change the narrative. The WEST Act is the product of extensive engagement and consultation with a diverse group of stakeholders – including farmers, technology innovators, industry and community leaders – and provides proactive, long-term solutions to California’s water challenges. This legislation offers a path forward for Californians, and I will continue to work with state leaders to find sustainable and achievable water solutions for California.

The month of October is dedicated to celebrating women in small business, and I'm proud to represent the state with the largest number of women-owned firms. California is home to 1.3 million women-owned businesses, including the Valley Brewing Company in my district in Stockton. Let's continue to support women entrepreneurs throughout the year and celebrate the contributions they make to our communities.

Covered California’s open enrollment starts today and runs through January 31st, 2018. To sign up, renew or learn more about your health insurance options, you can call Covered California’s Service Center at (800) 300-1506. You can also apply online at www.CoveredCA.com. Additionally, certified enrollers are available to assist you through the ‘Help on Demand’ feature.

This morning I took to the House floor to stand in support of children in my district and across this nation, and in strong opposition to H.R. 3922. This bill guts the Affordable Care Act's (ACA) Prevention and Public Health Fund––crucial funding for preventing and treating chronic diseases. Our district relies heavily on these resources to keep our children healthy, but Republicans are slashing these vital funds in yet another attempt to sabotage the ACA. Unfortunately, they are using the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) reauthorization, which has always been a bipartisan issue, to take core public health services away from children in need. It is critical that we reauthorize CHIP and community health centers, but we cannot do so by cutting essential funding and hurting our children.

Even if we were to stop carbon emissions immediately, we would still be faced with additional climate impacts. This was part of the discussion at yesterday's hearing on geoengineering. We must reduce our carbon emissions and prepare for the changes that are coming.

Don't forget to drop off your cards for the annual 'Holiday Cards for Our Troops' program. November 17th is the last day we'll be collecting them at my offices in Stockton and Antioch. The guidelines for participation are listed in the link below. https://mcnerney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-mcnerney-announces-2017-holiday-cards-for-the-troops-program
Veterans Day is a time to appreciate and honor the service and sacrifice made by our men and women in uniform. We cannot thank them enough.
Mary and I were honored to attend the Veterans Day ceremony in Stockton today, and had an opportunity to thank some of our nation’s heroes in person.

Don't forget to drop off your 'Holiday Cards for Our Troops' by this Friday, November 17th, at my Stockton or Antioch office. Many service members have told me that these cards, with their messages of encouragement and support, help boost morale for our service members when they cannot be home with their families and friends during the holiday season.

Today, I stood with my colleagues to say that, while the president has opted out of the Paris Agreement, I’m still in. I told the story of a trip Mary and I took to the Black Diamond Mines Regional Preserve. It’s a former coal field in my district with a graveyard on top of the hill. One day, Mary and I decided to hike up to that graveyard, where we saw the stones of those former miners and their families who dedicated their lives to making this a great country. As we were walking back down, thinking about the sacrifice those miners made, we looked out across the Delta and saw a magnificent sight: huge windmills turning slowly in the breeze. They were creating energy, but we also knew that they were creating new jobs and new opportunities. I’ll never forget that moment as we looked out on a beautiful view from the past to the future. That’s why I’m committed to continuing to combat climate change and ensure a future for this great nation.

The GOP's tax plan is all smoke and mirrors. They're claiming it's a tax cut for the middle class, but it's actually eliminating popular deductions that help millions of Americans - especially those in my district and throughout the state of California. I joined KPFA Radio to discuss the bill and why I'm voting against it.  Interview begins at the 45 minute mark. https://kpfa.org/episode/gop-tax-plan-police-killings-disabled-black-brown-people/

Today Republicans passed a plan purely on a partisan basis for political purposes. It will benefit corporations and the wealthiest Americans, largely at the expense of the middle class.  More than 6 million Californians will lose out on the benefits earned under the State and Local Tax deduction, and homeowners throughout the nation will see their finances take a hit from the new caps on mortgage interest deductions.  Higher education will be less affordable and accessible, and our students will continue to struggle in debt without the help of the student loan interest deduction.  Our tax code is in need of reform, but this plan, which was rushed through in just two weeks, is not the solution. The American people deserve more than that.

Yesterday, the Chairman of the Federal Communications Commission announced that in just a few weeks the Commission will vote on his proposal to eliminate net neutrality protections. These protections are the core of a free and open internet. They are vital for safeguarding free speech, which is essential for maintaining a robust democracy, and they are critical for fostering innovation. The Chairman’s proposal is flawed and misguided, and completely ignores the interests of consumers. I will continue to fight for strong net neutrality protections so that my constituents and all Americans can have access to a free and open internet.

Wishing you and your family a very happy Thanksgiving! Many of us will spend the day surrounded by family, friends and other loved ones, but many will spend this day serving to protect our country. Today, and everyday, I'm thankful to those who sacrifice time with their families to keep ours safe.

In my district, more than 31,000 small businesses rely on access to a free and open internet to grow, innovate, and thrive. Chairman Pai’s decision to abandon net neutrality would make it harder for small businesses to succeed. On a recent visit to Huddle – a coworking space in my district, where startups are putting forward cutting-edge ideas and working hard to get their businesses off the ground – business owners and employees expressed to me their fears about the devastating impact the elimination of net neutrality would have on their businesses.  A free and open internet is the backbone of innovation and critical for growing our local, regional, and national economy. I strongly oppose the FCC Chairman’s proposal. We must keep fighting to keep the current net neutrality protections in place.

I’ve heard from thousands of constituents who are concerned about the elimination of net neutrality and their online privacy rights. It’s incredibly frustrating that Republicans in Congress and at the FCC are not taking consumer protection seriously. Earlier this year, Republicans in Congress voted to eliminate broadband privacy protections. In response, I introduced the MY DATA Act to give consumers strong privacy and data security protections across the internet – none of my Republican colleagues signed on. And now the Trump FCC is expected to adopt Chairman Pai’s proposal to dismantle another critical area of consumer protection—net neutrality. I hope my Republican colleagues will stand up for consumers by opposing Chairman Pai’s proposal.  I hope they also join me in pushing for strong consumer privacy protections.

Over the past few weeks, Republicans in the House and Senate have pushed through two partisan tax bills that would do little more than slash corporate tax rates at the expense of the American taxpayer.  Between these two pieces of legislation, we would see the deficit skyrocket, higher education would become less affordable and accessible, and we would fall from our place as the world leader in innovation. All the while, these proposals would do nothing for the long-term strength of our economy, and would exacerbate our growing income inequality problem.  We need tax reform, but meaningful reform comes from working together. I urge my colleagues to come to the table and work with us on a tax plan that will benefit all Americans.

Right now, our country is engaged in an important conversation about sexual harassment. We have to listen to those coming forward and prevent this from happening to others. All allegations must be taken seriously and there must be transparency and accountability.  It doesn't matter who you are - whether it's in the halls of Congress, the private sector or anywhere else - all allegations must be investigated and everyone must be held accountable.

I'll be hosting a Congress at Your Corner in Brentwood this weekend! I hope you can join me this Saturday, between 2:30-3:30 PM at Willy's Bagels & Blends. I look forward to hearing from you about the issues you're most concerned about, and discussing a path forward.
I look forward to seeing everyone this afternoon at my Congress at Your Corner event. I’ll be at Willy's Bagels & Blends from 2:30-3:30 PM.

Thanks to everyone who came out to Saturday’s Congress at Your Corner! Mary and I had a great time catching up with you, and I look forward to continuing to fight for you and the important issues affecting our community.

Two years ago, I applauded America's leadership and the Paris Agreement's global commitment to combating climate change. Unfortunately, this administration has decided to withdraw the United States from this historical endeavor. But I'm not backing down. I will continue to fight for the future of our country and our planet. I'm still in.

Just sent a letter to Chairman Pai, requesting to address the Federal Communications Commission at Thursday's open meeting. Net neutrality is on the line, and I hope the Chairman will honor my request to speak before the Commission on behalf of all those who wish to maintain a free and open internet.

I’m very disappointed that the FCC Chairman has not only denied my request to address the full Commission, but has also denied my previous request to speak with him one-on-one prior to the vote on the elimination of net neutrality protections. Even more distressing is the fact that I am not alone. The Chairman has refused to speak with members from both sides of the aisle regarding the drastic action the Commission is about to take tomorrow.  Tomorrow’s vote is crucial to the free flow of ideas and the future of our economy. Net neutrality protections are the core of a free and open internet, simultaneously serving as a safeguard for free speech and a catalyst for innovation.  As members of Congress, we were sent to Washington to represent the American people – including the consumers, small business owners, and many more who will be directly affected by tomorrow’s vote. Thousands of constituents have reached out to me to express their concerns about the Chairman’s proposal to roll back net neutrality protections. The Chairman’s refusal to honor either of my requests – and the requests of other members – is also a refusal to hear the concerns of those Americans that we represent.
The Federal Communications Commission is streaming today's open meeting. https://www.fcc.gov/general/live

Thanks to Commissioner Clyburn for giving me the opportunity to submit my statement for the record. Today's decision to eliminate net neutrality protections is a dangerous step backwards, but the fight is not over. https://mcnerney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/repmcnerney-submits-written-statement-for-fcc-open-meeting
Today I joined my Democratic colleagues to stand in opposition to the GOP’s dangerous and harmful tax bill.

Yesterday, I spoke out against the disastrous Republican tax scam. Americans know that this plan will hurt them and our economy, and they have made their voices heard. But Republicans have pushed this legislation through anyway. Forget about investing in infrastructure, education or research, under this scam, Americans must now worry about the future of Medicare and Social Security.
Please join me for a town hall in Antioch to discuss issues of importance to you and our community.  For more information, please call my Antioch office at (925) 754-0716.
